Cedric Beust wrote:
> JUnit can do anything, all you need to do is write the
> code.
> 
> I'm talking about making this the default behavior of
> JUnit so that anybody who downloads junit.jar will see
> this behavior.

Like I said, it is: all you need to do is write a suite()
method, wrap the suite method in a decorator, and use it.
JUnit will already invoke the suite method by default, and
anybody who downloads JUnit sees this behaviour.

Oh, you want it to be easier? :) That's a different debate.
Yes, it could be a good idea to have, oh, suiteSetUp and
suiteTearDown methods to be used by the default test suite
(or suiteSetUp and suiteTearDown annotations if you prefer).
However, to say that JUnit doesn't have this behaviour
already is misleading, Cedric.

I'd rather have a facility to wrap the test suite in an
arbitary decorator than to have hardcoded suiteSetup and
suiteTeardown methods...

Robert.
